div.head: MAIN FOCUS
div.p: The main focus of the project is to study and develop novel eHealth services that will be enabled by the upcoming 5 th generation mobile technology (5G). The project will a) refine novel use cases related to eHealth that take advantage of and have need for the 5G capabilities, b) study and develop selected 5G network and service enablers as well as prototype eHealth applications for the use cases, c) pilot and validate the solutions in real environments and with end-users, including 5G test networks and hospitals, for example, d) and disseminate and exploit the results for the benefit of the society, science, and business. The work will be based on carefully selected, high-impact and industrydriven use cases for future eHealth, including hospital environment of the future, health@home, and emergency situations. The use cases will be detailed further, analysed, and experimented during the project's lifetime.

We define the project's vision as follows: "We envision a health monitoring system enabled by 5G-based heterogeneous networks by having various integrated wireless radio and cloud technologies, protocol designs, standards, and semantics. Such a system will satisfy application requirements in terms of connectivity, reliability, timeliness and throughput as well as bring benefits to individuals and the society."
In order to support the overall goal and vision, the more specific project objectives and workflow are detailed in the following list and illustrated in the simple figure below:
 The project aims to identify and refine novel, industry-driven use cases of eHealth that take advantage of 5G capabilities.
 The project aims to define the technology and business requirements and KPIs as well as the overall system architecture for the 5G-enabled eHealth services based on the use cases.
 The project aims to study and develop the 5G network and service enablers, required for meeting the connectivity and processing requirements of the target eHealth applications.
 The project aims to develop prototypes of selected eHealth applications and solutions based on the use cases.
 The project aims to integrate the networking solutions and applications as well as tackle any interoperability issues in terms of hardware and software to enable healthcare within 5G.
 The project will validate and pilot the solutions in real 5G test networks and end-user environments (e.g. hospitals), using eHealth IoT devices equipped with various radios and standard protocols.

 Finally, the project's results will be disseminated to public and scientific forums, contributed to standardization, as well as exploited for the benefits of the participating organizations and society.

div.head: State-of-the-art situation
div.p: While the standardisation of 5G is still on the way and its commercial system is projected to be rolled out from 2020, intensive research has been carried out to develop the Enabling Technologies required by 5G systems, which has generated promising results in some key areas of this development. The 5G Public-Private Partnership (5G PPP) within the Horizon 2020 programme of the EU is the biggest research program in the world on 5G. Under 5G PPP, initial 19 projects have started in 2015 as the first global response from Europe to these challenges, aiming at securing new 5G enabled markets in fields such as smart cities, e-health, intelligent transport, education and entertainment & media. 5G eHealth will require high reliable connectivity and transmission ability for remote monitoring.

div.head: eHealth
div.p: What is eHealth? According to the World Health Organization, eHealth is the use of information and communication technologies (ICT) for health, It can improve prevention, diagnosis, treatment, monitoring and management, and benefit the entire community by improving access to care and quality of care and by making the health sector more efficient. It includes information and data sharing between patients and health service providers, hospitals, health professionals and health information networks; electronic health records; telemedicine services; portable patient-monitoring devices, operating room scheduling software, robotized surgery and blue-sky research on the virtual physiological human. 1 The adoption of eHealth, matched by organisational changes and by other technical innovations can bring more than quality of life and sustainability for care, Despite the economic crisis, the market potential of eHealth is strong. The global telemedicine market has grown from $9.8 billion in 2010 to $11.6 billion in 2011, and continued to expand to $27.3 billion in 2016, representing a compound annual growth rate of 18.6%. The well being market enabled by digital technologies is rapidly growing. The convergence between wireless communication technologies and healthcare devices and between health and social care is creating new businesses. Redesigning the delivery of care and the 'silver economy' are highly promising markets. 2 eHealth as a strategical objective in the world: More than half of World Health Organization (WHO) Member States now have an eHealth strategy, and 90% of eHealth strategies reference the objectives of UHC (Universal Health Coverage) or its key elements. A large number of countries report at least one mHealth initiative (83%). Despite the rapid growth, however, very few WHO Member States reported evaluations of government-sponsored mHealth programmes, thereby limiting knowledge of what works well and what mistakes to avoid. 3 In the new "EU 2020 Strategy" (European Commission, 2010a) the ageing process and healthcare are included among the grand societal challenges Europe is facing and must turn into opportunities: Public health expenditure in the EU's 27 Member States was on average 5.9% of GDP in 1990, rose to 7.2% of GDP in 2010, and the projections show that expenditure may continue to grow to 8.5% of GDP in 2060 due to the ageing population and other socioeconomic and cultural factors. In addition, the long-term care expenditure projection would on average almost double over the projection period. Concurrently, the working age contingent is expected to fall dramatically from 61% to 51% of the total population while the share of the elderly (65+) and very old (80+) population in the EU is projected to grow respectively from 17.4% in 2010 to 30.0% in 2060 and from 4.7% in 2010 to 12.1% in 2060. The impact of these changes is already being felt today and is particularly acute at a time of increased pressure on public budgets, a steady decline in the number of health personnel, higher incidence of chronic diseases and growing demands and expectations from citizens for higher quality services and social care. The existing models of health care provision, often subject to fragmentation and insufficient coherence, appear to be one of the main causes limiting efficiency of interventions and quality of health outcomes. There is a trend for descentralization that is changing the way that countries envisaged the provision of health care system.

eHealth adoption: current situation in Europe: Some of the indicators that emerged from the combined efforts that the EC, the OECD, and WHO launched in 2010 in Barcelona is Health Information Exchange (HIE); Telehealth; and Personal Health Records (PHR).
 Health Information Exchange (HIE) is the process of electronically transferring / sharing / enabling access to patient health information and data.
 Telehealth is the use of broadband-based technological platforms for the purpose of providing health services, medical training and health education over a distance.
 Personal Health Record (PHR) are electronic systems allowing patients to have secure access to, and manage, their health information.

Reported results in 2013 show that primary care in Europe is reaching almost 100% access to basic ICT: about 97% report having and using a computer connected to the Internet during consultation. But access and use of mobile devices, broadband, and high-speed Internet still present ample margins for improvement. There are some clear bottlenecks in terms of 'electronically embedded' system inter-connection with other healthcare players, technical inter-operability, system resilience, and security. Limited adoption of Health Information Exchange (HIE) is surely also a consequence of such bottlenecks. 4 In hospitals, eHealth uptake in the EU27+3 countries and notable growth areas are PACS (Picture Archiving and Commuications Systems) and wireless infrastructures. PACS usage in hospitals is 70% today, while wireless infrastructure usage is 66%. (Error! Reference source not found.) Areas which have not shown considerable progress are: EHR usage, health information exchange and patient online access. Hospitals which have eHealth functionalities mostly use them routinely. This is important because, overall, it justifies the investment into eHealth.

eHealth needs in Data and Connectivity: a case for 5G technology and its impact: The lack of information sharing with patients is a complex area as it touches on privacy requirements, legal requirements and security issues as well 1 eHealth definition, https://ec.europa.eu/health/ehealth/policy_en 2 EHealth Action Plan 2012-2020, https://ec.europa.eu/health/sites/health/files/ehealth/docs/com_2012_736_en.pdf 3 Global diffusion of eHealth: Making universal health coverage achievable, http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/252529/1/9789241511780-eng.pdf?ua=1. 4 Benchmarking Deployment of eHealth among General Practitioners, (2013), https://ec.europa.eu/digital-singlemarket/en/news/benchmarking-deployment-ehealth-among-general-practitioners-2013-smart-20110033.

as the more obvious structural and infrastructural problems. The exchange of clinical care information, radiology reports and medication lists, although improved slightly, but still remains an issue. The non-implementation of telemonitoring of outpatients, has gone from 89% non-implementation to 76% non-implementation between 2010 and 2012. 5 Telehealth is only implemented to a minor extent and is mostly available for holding consultations with other healthcare practitioners (31%). However, when telehealth capabilities are implemented, they are mostly used (usage in around 90% of the surveyed hospitals on average). This demonstrates that the capability offers genuine utility for healthcare professionals.

A lot of information currently gathered in EHR and PHR, as well as this gathered by the citizens themselves can be used in implementing telehealth and telemonitoring. 5G technology has the potential to bring such services to implementation and adoption, as it is explained in section 1.2 Rationale for the project.

5G and cloud computing 5G: The standardization of a new 5G air interface is foreseen by 3GPP to be divided in phases where the first phase, with a finalization targeted during 2018, is focusing on early commercial deployments and a subset of the 5G requirements. The second phase of the standardization, targeted to be finalized at the end of 2019, targets fulfillment of the full set of 5G requirements for various use cases like massive Machine Type Communication (mMTC), operation in unlicenced frequency bands, positioning, satellite integration, V2X and more. In this context, the advent of 5G cellular systems, with the availability of a connectivity technology which is at once truly ubiquitous, reliable, scalable, and cost-efficient, is considered as a potentially key driver for the yet-to emerge global IoT.

The 3GPP initiative has successfully developed the radio technology of LTE close the capacity limit of a single physical wireless channel. However, in terms of total wireless network capacity, power efficiency, latency, reliability and hardware cost reduction there is a growing need to further enhance the available standards for wireless communication. In order to address these issues, the 3GPP initiative has started work towards a 5G system.

The key performance requirements of 5G for International Mobile Telecommunications (IMT) IMT-2020 are expected to be approved in November 2017. In that requirement, the peak data rate for one mobile station is 20 Gbps, with a user experienced data rate of 100 Mbps. It should support very dense deployments of terminals, 1 million devices / km 2 . The requirements also specify supporting low-end battery powered devices with 10 years batty life. 5G is targeting co-use of licensed and non-licensed spectrum (Licensed Assisted Access -LAA) and is also enabling use of a much wider range of frequencies (defined for both sub 6 GHz and above 6 GHz frequencies). There will be defined a New Radio (NR) interface for 5G.

While earlier standards have provided general purpose connectivity platforms, 5G is aiming to provide features specific to verticals, i.e. services for markets such as automotive, energy, healthcare, city management and more. In these verticals, use cases are defined, which in term specify the technical requirements for that use case. The healthcare uses cases in 5G include assets and interventions management in hospitals, robotics, remote monitoring of health or wellness data and smarter medications.

Software-defined networking (SDN) is an emerging architecture that is dynamic, manageable, cost-effective, and adaptable, making it ideal for the high-bandwidth, dynamic nature of today's applications. This architecture decouples the network control and forwarding functions enabling the network control to become directly programmable and the underlying infrastructure to be abstracted for applications and network services. The OpenFlow® protocol is a foundational element for building SDN solutions.

SDN can provide several benefits for businesses trying to move into a virtual environment: Programmable networks (e.g. OpenStack, Puppet, and Chef), centralized management, reduced CapEx and OpEx, and increased agility and flexibility. SDN helps organizations rapidly deploy new applications, services, and infrastructure to quickly meet changing business goals and objectives.

Technologies based on SDN include Open Signaling, Active Networking, NETCONF, ForCES, 4D, Ethane, RCP, SANE, SS7, and a lot of commercial vendors are now providing SDN capabilities. SDN still faces some challenges, since it was originally developed with high-demand environments like data centers in mind.

Network functions virtualization (NFV) is a network architecture concept that virtualizes entire classes of network node functions into building blocks that may connect, or chain together, to create communication services. As opposed to traditional server-virtualization techniques, a virtualized network function (VNF) may consist of one or more virtual machines running different software and processes, on top of standard high-volume servers, switches and storage devices, or even cloud computing infrastructure, instead of having custom hardware appliances for each network function. For example, a virtual session border controller could be deployed to protect a network without the typical cost and complexity of obtaining and installing physical network protection units. Other examples of NFV include virtualized load balancers, firewalls, intrusion detection devices and WAN accelerators.

By using NFV, it is possible to run network functions on general-purpose hardware, to take network functions in and out of service, to scale them up and down easily, deploy functions where you need them, and to automate service delivery with orchestration. Hence, similarly to SDN, it can offer the benefits of reduced CapEx and OpEx by reducing the need for hardware upgrades, personnel training, and resources for deploying and maintaining network functions. Furthermore, it allows operators to deliver agility and flexibility and to lower hardware costs by replacing dedicated appliances with shared servers, speeding up time to market, supporting on-demand pay-as-you go deployment models, etc. Enterprise NFV can save time and increase the network uptime and flexibility. Its immediate applications are numerous, such as virtualization of mobile base stations, platform as a service (PaaS), content delivery networks (CDN), fixed access and home environments. There are numerous initiatives underway to specify, align and promote NFV carrier-grade capabilities such as ETSI NFV Proof of Concept, ATIS Open Platform for NFV Project, Carrier Network Virtualization Awards, Open vSwitch's (OVS), Accelerated Open vSwitch (AVS), and various supplier ecosystems.

Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) is an emergent architecture where cloud-computing capabilities and an IT service environment are extended to the edge of networks leveraging mobile base stations. As a promising edge technology, it can be applied to mobile, wireless and wireline scenarios, using software and hardware platforms, located at the network edge in the vicinity of end-users, providing seamless integration of multiple application service providers and vendors towards mobile subscribers, enterprises and other vertical segments. It is an important component in the 5G architecture which supports a variety of innovative applications and services where ultra-low latency and high bandwidth are required as well as real-time access to radio network information that can be leveraged by applications.

MEC is implemented based on a virtualized platform that leverages recent advancements in NFV, information-centric networking (ICN) and SDN. Specifically, NFV enables a single edge device to provide computing services to multiple mobile devices by creating multiple virtual machines (VMs) for simultaneously performing different tasks or operating different network functions. On the other hand, ICN provides an alternative end-to-end service recognition paradigm for MEC, shifting from a host-centric to an information-centric one for implementing context-aware computing. SDN allows MEC network administrators to manage services via function abstraction, achieving scalable and dynamic computing. A main focus of MEC research is to develop these general network technologies so that they can be implemented at the network edges.

The European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI), together with major companies, is currently working on the development of an MEC standard under an Industry Specification Group (ISG), with a goal of allowing efficient and seamless integration of applications from different equipment vendors, telco service providers, OTT service providers and third parties.

5G IoT: The advent of 5G communications represents a potentially disruptive element in the context of a large variety of communication technologies, such as Bluetooth Low Energy in Personal Area Networks, and Zigbee in Home Automation systems. The increased data rate, reduced end-to-end latency, and improved coverage with respect to 4G hold the potential to cater for even the most demanding of IoT applications in terms of communication requirements. Its support for large amounts of devices enables the vision of a truly global Internet of Things. In addition, for its focus on the integration of heterogeneous access technologies, 5G may play the role of a unified interconnection framework, facilitating a seamless connectivity of "things" with the Internet.

Considering MTC Generation tradeoff, the stringent requirements of M2M, the 2G-technology family, i.e. GSM and GPRS/EGPRS, is ideal as power consumption and cost are low, coverage global and the eco-system is developed; however, from an economic point of view it is perceived to be much more viable to revise the bands for next generation systems. The 3G family, i.e. UMTS and HSPA, has a lower power efficiency and higher modem cost than 2G. The capabilities exceed the requirements of many low end IoT applications and may therefore be a less preferable choice for such applications. 4G technologies, i.e LTE and LTE-A, are interesting again since the capabilities meet the requirements for very demanding MTC applications; the air interface, OFDM(A), allows the scaling of the bandwidth according to needs. Modem cost in early LTE releases is however an issue and the coverage is in some markets still patchy even if coverage increases quickly on a global level. A further argument for use of 4G LTE for MTC applications is to benefit from improved spectral efficiency and the bandwidth flexibility offered by 4G systems and longevity of the technology as a future cellular system. Uptake, due to a rather patchy 4G coverage, is only catching up now and the challenge of adapting a 4G LTE system (that was specifically designed for efficient broadband communication) to also deliver and support MTC applications remains.

5G may thus be a timely technology offering lower cost, lower energy consumption and support for very large number of devices. The requirements and standardization initiatives which lead into these design developments are based in 3GPP technologies and their continuous enhancements are staged in different releases in 3GPP (Figure 1). An important aspect contributing to the success of 3GPP technologies for cellular use is maintaining backward compatibility with legacy releases and tight interworking between technologies and efficient roaming support, which is also key for M2M/MTC applications that require support for mobility. In Rel-10 and in Rel-12 SA2 worked on efficient transmission of Small Data Transmissions and Low Power Consumption UEs. Ever since, the amount of study items and technical specifications for MTC has increased steadily and are now a core ingredient of standardization work. One of the most interesting features of MTC is the ability to offer SLAs even for the most critical and demanding industry applications. Such agreements can be honoured since the spectrum is exclusively owned by the operators, in contrast to the ISM band used by Zigbee/LP-Wifi/LPWAs. Despite the convincing advantages, some serious challenges remain to make MTC an underlying connectivity backbone for the Internet of Things. These challenges are pertinent at device and networking levels, and when it comes to a viable business proposition.

div.head: Ensuring QoS and security for eHealth applications
div.p: QoS: The wide variety of e-Health services impose different QoS requirements on underlying networks. One aspect is delay tolerance, with service requirements ranging from strict real-time and delay-intolerant data transmission (e.g., tele-consultation services involving transmission of patient physiological parameters in emergency situations) to delay-tolerant services (e.g., access to a patient's EHR; home tele-monitoring). Another aspect is application data sensitivity to loss, with conversational voice-based applications often tolerating a certain packet loss, while data transmission (e.g., transfer of medical images) being highly loss intolerant. A significant amount of related work deals with performance requirements of e-Health services and evaluated network capabilities in meeting those requirements.

Salehi and Mirhadi6 , categorize the importance of various QoS parameters for different fields of e-Health. The analysis of prioritization and resource allocation schemes for various types of telemedicine traffic delivered over wireless networks has been addressed by Vergados 7 , as well as by Qiao and Koutsakis 8 by employing simulation techniques. Further studies have more specifically focused on evaluating support for the delivery of emergency telemedicine services over high-speed 3G networks 910 , and other wireless networks 11 , with evaluation results showing generally reliable performance. Apart from emergency scenarios, 3G networks have been analyzed in the support of various tele-consultation services involving the delivery of high-definition images 12 , such as the delivery of ultrasound still and streaming images in robotic tele-ultrasonography systems 13 . Projects such as MobiHealth, HealthService24, and MyHeart have focused on developing systems for continuous tele-monitoring of patient vital signals and their transmission to healthcare institutes using 2.5/3G networks.

Much less research has been dedicated on involving mathematical methods for evaluating support for e-Health services in the context of next generation network standards. Traditional approaches applied to the development, maintenance and deployment of eHealth services using such standards do not provide adequate support in terms of methods, languages and tools. However, much research has been devoted to methodologies for QoS evaluation in the context of service-oriented architectures, including predictive and empirical techniques14
5G and Security: For 5G eHealth applications and services, the state of the art is incipient and almost not available.

From the 5G PPP group, as considered in its "White Paper on eHealth Vertical Sector"15 , all healthcare use cases require a strong security due to their vital nature. 5G needs to provide a strong and reliable authentication system. Sensors must also be authenticated by the network and associated to the patient identity. Indeed, patients want to be sure that there is no identity theft and no private data distributed to unauthorized parties. In addition, doctors want to be sure of the data quality to avoid biased diagnostics and ubsequent liability consequences. It strongly calls for a security technology like SIM or embedded SIM as explained in a recent report from GSMA 16 .

As identified also by the 5G PPP group when dealing with eheatlh aplpications, adequate security mechanisms are also needed to take into account the limited capabilities of constrained sensors, as well as the additional vulnarabilities if part of the security functions are offloaded to the cloud. Some important research objectives in this field are as follows:

 Identity management: Networks should uniquely identify and authenticate health devices/wearables and control their remote access with a timely update of certificates. This is specially compromised when working on 5G densified small cell deployment with overlay coverage through coexisting heterogeneous networks (Hetnets)17

 Privacy protection: Personal information may be disclosed, but only with the individual's knowledge and consent. 18 Data and message encryption and protection: Data and messages exchanged should be secured and checked for consistency. In this sense, mechanisms also to protect user privacy based on IMSI encryption are under scope 19 .

 Update of security mechanisms: The security mechanisms and algorithms should be developed such that they can be updated to adapt to new hackers threats. Research on this topic focuses on flexible and autonomous security service implementation with new paradigms as the Security Trust Zone in 5G Networks. 20 Machine learning based cyber security product Cybernate will contribute to communication security between eHealth devices and health personnel which are physically distant. Cybernate observes the log files and warn against abnormal activity, also it will learn from previous malwares and vulnerabilities and alert on 0-day attacks that are caused by new malwares that are unknown. Artificial intelligence based predictive health agent will analyze and come up with issues that may impact a group of people based on their health readings and environmental issues (i.e. location-based aspects that can affect health).

div.head: Beyond state-of-the art
div.p: Our project will advance the state of the art and state of practice at least on the following fronts:

Novel use cases of eHealth, for which 5G can act as a catalyst. The use cases will be created in co-creation with end users and technological professionals from the areas of 5G network technologies, health technologies, IoT and data-analysis. The initial use cases are described below this chapter, and they will be used as a basis of discussion during the project, but the final and more detailed use cases will be defined during the project. The aim of the use cases definition is to find scenarios, which definitely need novel networking technologies such as 5G to function. The use cases will be used to specify the requirements and the technical functionalities of the systems.

div.head: Arificial Intelligence -based Clinical Decision Support Systems
div.p: for heterogeneous eHealth services. The project will advance the methods, which intelligently utilize the data from various different sources and finds novel methods supporting decision making inside the clinics and during the emergency situations, for example inside the ambulance. The project consortium includes health and medical device manufacturers, as well as sensor manufacturers, and eHealth service providers. All these provide data, which is relevant for diagnosis and better support for health. The collected health data may include for example video images, high-resolution images, data from the environment and vital data from a patient. Artificial intelligence methods will be utilized to analyze the collected data and to make clinical decisions more efficient and quick and also available outside the clinics. 5G provides such capabilities, that the decisions can be made quickly, with small delays and close, without sending all the data to the cloud. The project and cooperation within the consortium provides an opportunity to create innovations in fusing data from various sources and in developing intelligent algorithms for clinical decision support.

Optimal connectivity through integrated 5G and other wireless network technologies. 5G will integrate the existing 3GPP and IEEE 802.11 systems with the emerging 5G radio technologies in order to provide ubiquitous connectivity and enable smooth transition. The project will also look at the utilization of heterogeneous technologies in connecting the services, depending on the use case and requirements, as well as their seamless integration into the overall network system. For example, bluetooth technologies are currently widely used for eHealth systems. However, it has several disadvantages to provide services for the future healthcare needs (e.g., high battery drainage, security problem, interference, limited data rate, very short-range communication, short lifetime). In order to overcome these limitations, the project will consider optical camera communication (OCC), a sub-system of the optical wireless communication (OWC), which uses multiple LEDs as the transmitter and a camera or image sensor (IS) as the receiver. The technology seems promising for the envisioned future 5G eHealth system, as OCC can provide stable connectivity even if the distance is increased, and finally it's not harmful for the human body. Moreover, camera used in OCC system can record ultra-high-defination video that can help for real-time monitoring of patient, AR, and VR applications. Regarding OCC, the project will advance the state of the art in terms of including it as a part of the overall communication and service architecure as well as developing new eHealth services and applications on top. mCCN architecture will be used together with the applications in order to provide inherent security and mobility support. mCCN is also a paradigm for faster content delivery along with its caching mechanism.

div.head: Adoption of 5G in enabling medical
div.p: IoT. The emergence of 5G cellular systems, with the availability of a connectivity technology, which is at once truly ubiquitous, reliable, scalable, and cost-efficient, is considered as a potentially key driver for the yet-to emerge global IoT. Therefore, 5G communications represents a disruptive element and new impulse because increase data rate, reduced end-to-end latency, and improved coverage with respect to 4G. That allows a big potential to create the most demanding of IoT applications in terms of communication requirements. In addition, it allows to support for large amounts of devices enables the vision of a truly global Internet of Things (that is, one of the major differences between the 4G and 5G design). Dealing 5G connections and deployment of the technology, there are different options to spread this new technology and advantages in its first steps, one of the main opportunities to maintain all the value current medical devices have is providing a unique device as the centre of the security, reliability and efficiency. The Health^5G project will advance the state of the art in this front by being a front-runner in adopting the new radio technology for medical IoT devices. With 5G still in the standardization phase, especially regarding the IoT connectivity, the project will also have a possibility to contribute to the 5G standardization based on the requirements and practical experiences coming from the use cases, integrations, and pilots

div.head: Safety and security assurance in heterogeneous networks for eHealth applications and services.
div.p: From the point of safety and security assurance in heterogeneous networks innovation achieved at the end of the project beyond the state of the art will include new strong and security features of protocols and algorithms dealing with the security aspects in the context of the 5G eHealth environment. Particularly relevant will be those supporting the generation of baseline concept based on normal behavior adapted in real time to each scenario, and the capacity to analysis / identification of abnormal behavior patterns through baseline comparison. Specific techniques for analysis / discovering types of sensitive data in combination with automatic determination of baseline of good behaviour for network and devices, will derived in the paradigm of "Security by default" and "privacy by design" in the arena of 5G networks with the particularity of eHealth scenarios and application.

div.head: Use cases
div.p: The project will develop novel technologies and advancements in the context of the following initial, 5G-inspired use cases, selected by the consortium. The use cases will be detailed furter during the project.

div.head: Use case 1: Connectivity inside hospital
div.p: This use-case will enhance the connectivity and data transfer inside a hospital. The steps taken will be: 1) real-time data collection, storage to cloud and integration to hospitals SW tools and micro-operated 5G network; 2) transfer and display to care personnel patient data collected by various sensors and imaging devices; and 3) develop 5G capabilities to support the needed functionalities.

Sub-use cases and pilots will include wireless operating room and remote surgery, robot assisted patient monitoring, collecting patient data at the ward or ICU, Advanced Nursing Cart and Advanced Hospital stretcher, both enabled to collect data form different hospital elements, AR/VR at hospital.

Need for 5G: high security, micro-operator possibility, transferring large image data, transferring high-quality video, low (or no)-latency, collection of large amount of patient data, edge computing for faster data-analysis. Software solutions will be based on both 5G technology and WebRTC technology in order to enable the development of application for various platforms including web-and mobile applications.

div.head: Use case 2: Health@home
div.p: By enhancing connectivity at home, outside of home or in a nursing home, the use case will include point of care testing, patient generated health data collection and video capture in acute situations. The steps taken will be: 1) implement real-time data collection (personal sensor data and video), storage to cloud and integration to health information systems and 5G network; 2) display the data to the person, or to care personnel if needed or requested (services); 3) develop 5G capabilities to support the needed functionalities.

div.head: Sub-use cases will include:
div.p: - -Home Health&WellBeing Gateway: In many environments health and wellbeing data (considered important and private) has to be collected and prepared to be introduced in different final servers with a secure and reliable connection.

-Mobile applications for health status monitoring and critical states prediction for patience having their treatment at home (on the example of nocturnal hypoglycemia in patients with diabetes) (KPI) 21 , as well as robot-assisted health monitoring and ubiquitous electrocardiogram monitoring in real time.

Need for 5G: high security, transferring high-quality video data with low (or no)-latency, collection of large amount of patient data, analysing video images, data fusion, edge computing for faster data-analysis.

div.head: Use case 3: Emergency situations
div.p: The enhancement of the connectivity in emergency situations is the target of the third use case. The steps taken will be: 1) implement real-time data collection from sensors and imaging devices, storage to cloud and integration to service systems; 2) test and design services for the emergency room and care personnel; and 3) develop 5G capabilities to support the needed functionalities.

div.head: Sub-use cases:
div.p:  Smart Ambulances, where crucial data can be exchanged, including images, leading to AR/VR medical services on both sides. Video conferencing could also be available when needed, supported by mobile applications and smart sensors, e.g. gesture recognition. Cases, such as driver seizure and in-vehicle emergency could also be tested. Seamless transfer of the patient, the sensors and the measurements (e.g. ECG) along the path of emergency siteambulance -hospital emergency unit -operating table, will be piloted.

 Large events such as a major marathon run: Participants are equipped with sensors that monitor their condition, so that fast response can be obtained in emergencies and possible real time video streaming to doctors / hospital unit can be created.

Need for 5G: high security, micro-operator possibility, transferring large image data, transferring high-quality video, low (or no)-latency, collection of large amount of patient data, edge computing for faster data-analysis. As a summary, the 4G/5G URLLC and 4G/5G mMTC technologies are required.

div.head: Rationale for the project
div.p: As shown above, eHealth presents great potential, but there are some clear barriers that empede the full realization of its benefits. Some of the barriers are related to technology, such as faster communications and broader networks, faster mobile connections in large buildings and in remote areas, support a context with several devices and sensors, and assure greater security capabilities and availability, and above all reliability. 5G technology is a good candidate for providing solutions, and these solutions will have to be adequately designed and validated at an early stage. It is also expected that 5G will enable the Internet of Things (IoT) and will transform business and entire industries. The new paradimg will require new IT technology for communications between, persons, objects and the whole ecosystem. The results of this project will give clear quality insights and quantified expected impact of the 5G technology, as well as understanding of the role that this technology can play in the transformation of health and care towards an affordable, citizen centered empowering paradigm. In more detail, the challenges that 5G could provide a solution to are:
Data collection, analysis and transfer  5G Low latency and analytical power

A hospital system includes hardware computers, mobile devices, equipment etc.) as well as software for data collection, transfer, storing and processing of clinical documents, and other types of information. The connections and transfer of data, can be wired or wireless. Wired connection is reliable but it limits spatially the viewing of data. Mobility would support access to health records wherever and whenever needed, e.g. at the side of the patient.

During an operation, a wireless operating theatre is becoming necessary, since the many device cables present always a possible hazard. Wireless transfer of data is challenging because wireless signals sometimes cannot reach all places in buildings. Medical images and videos, which are the essential part for many medical investigations and operations, require enough bandwidth to be transmitted properly. In addition, there is a growing amount of information that needs to be transferred, due the better imaging facilities and detailed analysis results, monitoring of the patient in wards with various sensors etc.

Similar challenges exist when the services are delivered outside the hospitals, i.e. at home or outdoors. Monitoring health and treatment at home, or responding to emergencies involves real time collection (IoT), analysis (edge and cloud computing) and transfer of large amounts of data, as well as fast responses. But the challenges include also resilience of the network and availability in all kinds of rural and urban environments.

div.head: Security and Interoperability  5G Security layers, architecture and interfaces
div.p: Another important aspect is security at all levels. Healthcare data have to be legally protected. This fact creates many problems in access of data by professionals and patients who are not physically in the hospital, as well as integrating data that come from outside the hospital, e.g. In telemedicine scenarios where new, more effective and efficient healthcare processes are being introduced. The complexity of eHealth systems is very high, which renders information quality (completeness, integrity), accessibility and availability a very challenging task.

A core issue for an effective and secure use of these services is to ensure a high level of interoperability and guarantee that information is transmitted safely through individual information systems, health service institutions, healthcare providers and patients. For example, the cloud services among different cloud service providers, local or external clouds, must be based on universally applied standards and an agreed-upon framework or some open protocols/APIs for secure information exchange and services integration.

The 5G^Health project consortium includes company partners that can provide reallistic needs for the scenarios of the use cases described in 1.4, and research partners capable of developing and piloting the needed functionalities and solutions. Pilots and tests will take place, for example:

 In Finland: at VTT's 5G test network environment that allows testing the developed networking and service functionalities in a real 5G environment, including the latest technology and advancements (e.g. 5G PoC radio, eMBMS, and MEC). The OYS TestLab is another facility, situated at the Oulu University Hospital and it is an innovation testbed, where hospital technology can be tested and piloted. It can be used by companies and industry, but it also aims at providing insights and knowledge tot he hospital professionals about available technologies and their capabilties. Since 2016, a 5G test network has been installed, so that 5G based services and products can be tested.  In Spain: Televés has a Showroom and trial facilities that can be used for piloting in the project: Showroom (Full Scale facilities, Linkedto R&D facilities, Linked to Televés solutions); Televés House (Bedroom, Bathroom, Livingroom, kitchen); Televés Hotel facilities (Hotel Room, Hotel Reception, Hotel Livingroom); Televés Hospital facilities (Televés Hospital reception, Televés Hospital Room, Televés Geriatric Room).

div.head: Technological innovation and strategic relevance
div.p: Health5G provides innovation both in networking and eHealth area. The project brings together the knowledge of networking experts, medical device manufacturers, sensor developers, eHealth service developers and end users, with the aim to find novel ways to improve health care. The project will innovate to find out those health related use cases that are strategically most significant and try to develop networking, IoT, medical devices, sensors, dataanalysis methods and IoT -technologies that support these use cases.

The major innovation of Health^5G lies in the development of novel eHealth services, and in the background in the technologies that enable these services. The research and development includes novel intelligent algorithms, 5G networking technologies, connectivity, medical IoT and sensors. In addition, the project tackles interoperability in terms of hardware and software to enable healthcare within 5G. Commercial off-the-shelf physiological IoT devices are equipped with various radios and standard. The aim is to build a health monitoring system with heterogeneous networks by having various wireless radio technologies, protocol designs, standards, and semantics. Such a system should satisfy application requirements in terms of connectivity, reliability, timeliness and throughput. Impacts on the architecture of the evolving 5G networks will be identified and brought into standardization. The developed tools are tested in "as real as possible" situations and reported through scientific and public dissemination channels.

The expected impact is supported by the demonstrations and pilots benefiting of the joint developed technologies in actual environment with people at risk and patients focusing on validation and impact assessment. This will provide that final organizations could become early adopters of the solutions.

div.head: Methods of measuring of impact in the project
div.p: A model of digital transformation is being developed by VTT, which has the potential to assist organizations in finding the position in digitilazation and in understanding the process of the transformation on their point of view. The model is presented in Figure 2: Model for tackling digital transformation: In 5G^Health, the impact and the potential of the 5G technology will be studied for each of the use cases and for the companies involved, based on parts of the Digital Transformation model. The study will focus on the fact that 5G technology can act as tool and as an opportunity for leading a company or an organization to digitilisation. It will pinpoint a role in the drivers, the opportunities, the analysis of the possible scenarios as well as in the definition of goals. These attributes will be used in the comparative study between the benefits of the digitilization using current network technologies as compared to using 5T technologies, for each case in the project and assess the real impact on the point of view of enabling better services, providing sustainability and instigating new business opportunities.

div.head: Relationships with related European or national projects:
div.p: A relevant European project for one of the detailed use cases above was carried out by the partner Inova DE. The Eurostars project CAST E!10291 lead by Inova DE aims to create a prototype system to analyze long streams of ECG signals (over weeks or months), composed by a t-shirt with textile-based sensors and a platform that allow the transmission of the ECG to the cardiologist wirelessly. The system aims to provide real-time monitoring for remote patients with the benefits of longterm analysis, early warning and diagnosis support for the cardiologist. This development constitutes the backbone of a seamless medical device supported by the mobile broadband network. It will be concluded at the end of 2018.
The project will also effectively utilize the previous projects that has been working around the subject. Below we mention some of these projects.

This present project proposal will further enhance the functionalities of the ongoing project CAST. By the end of 2018 the prototype will be at TRL6 and presents the functional platform for integrating more services directed a supporting the cardiologist workflow. This means that the platform still needs to be improved and certain aspects of the current mobile networks and the future 5G need to be address and the QoS confirmed and maintained, especially with large loads of personal medical data being transmitted in crowded or remote places. This prior-art is a perfect test-bench to make a test in a large ecosystem of patients and guarantee its efficiency, accuracy and reliability in the German national context. Specifically with the safe communication chat between patient and cardiologist; this was not addressed before. To do so, we will collaborate with the Medical University of Heidelberg to obtain feedback about the system and its validation near the cardiologists and patients and integration into the clinical workflow.

As part of the Celtic+ project SENDATE Secure-DCI a demonstrator is currently being developed within the Open SDN / NFV Lab in Berlin. That software and lab infrastructure will be used for eHealth^5G project.

Wireless Lab for Business, Finland (VTT) WILLE (ERDF) developed a co-creation model for designing healthcare services in a hospital test environment. Some of the scenarios included 5G use in a wireless hospital. The Tekes 5GTN and 5GTN+ projects will relate closely to Health^5G, as they have built the 5G test network infrastructure utilized by VTT in the project. Health^5G will bring an important addition to the existing test network projects thanks to the real eHealth vertical use cases and applications deployed and showcased using the test network.
In SIGMONA, a related CELTIC PLUS project, Ericsson Turkey and Turkish consortium set-up a SDN environment and run a trial demo of it.

div.head: National perspective for Finland
div.p: Overall social protection expenditure in Finland amounted to 31.6 percent of GDP, or USD 73.56 billion, in 2015, while sickness and health sector accounted for 23 percent, or USD 17 billion. Universal coverage is accessible for all citizens and permanent residents in the country, with a range of comprehensive health services delivered primarily by publicly owned and operated providers. In 2015, approximately 82 percent of services and programs within the system were funded through public expenditure and private financing accounted for 18 percent.

Finland is very advanced in its use of IT systems within the healthcare industry, relative to other European nations. eHealth has been part of the health and social care strategy since 1995. The strategy was built around the principle of citizen-centred and seamless service structures. One of the main targets of the strategy was the horizontal integration of services (social, primary and secondary care). Citizens and patients were envisioned as informed and participative actors in the healthcare delivery process, placing specific emphasis on the following targets: adoption of digital patient and client records at all levels of care, combined with nationwide interoperability between distributed legacy systems, and supported by a high level of security and privacy protection (Ministry of Social Affairs and Health 1998). During the past 20 years many plans and efforts have been made to align political visions closer to everyday routine health and social care performance. During this roadmap of implementation, the architecture of the solutions has become clearer and is underpinned by legislation on health care information infrastructures. Today, individuals within the healthcare system have widespread, simple access to convenient ePrescription and eArchive services. 2223 As Finland is undergoing a process of health and social care system reform due to come into force on 1 January 2019, eHealth and eWelfare were identified as an important tool in modernizing the system. Thus, the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health upgraded the Finnish national e-health and e-welfare strategy.

Examples of major eHealth services in Finland are the Finnish Electronic Patient Record system (KanTa), which allows every citizen to access his or her medical records, as well as prescription services. Physicians also utilize this database not only to view patient records, but also to gain access to the Picture Archiving and Communications System (PACS), from which they can see and send relevant information to other entities within the healthcare system. The Finnish government has recognized that there is a need for a more reliable and consistent health IT communications and EHR sharing between municipalities, regional districts, and private care providers. Integration of health information systems and cross-organizational, even cross-country processing of patient information are emerging themes that need to be covered in the future. Digitalization of the Finnish health care system and integration with the social care system builds a basis for an ecosystem, which provides new opportunities also for enterprises. Mobile health services (mHealth) are increasingly compensating for services that have been tied to a certain infrastructure or place. A common infrastructure for mHealth software is currently missing. Telemedecine is recognised as a leading eHealth subsector. Health IT and telemedicine in Finland are expected to gain an even more visible presence in the near future, as far-reaching goals that the sector has been allotted in recent years show continued promise in improving the healthcare system.

div.head: National perspective for France
div.p: The emerging 5G networks is based on service oriented model, and eHealth is one of the key aspect of 5G technology. In this context, the France eHealth move forward to promote and federate the start-ups of the e-Health and Wellness sector in France to help them to gain readability and visibility, and express common positions on shared issues. These actors can work on web platforms, social networks in health, mobile applications and connected objects of health, data in health, machine to machine, conversational digital interface. In addition, France eHealth aims to federate SME, large companies, research clusters, healthcare professionals, patients and users who are involved in e-Health as part of an eco-system. This vision is the answer to a twofold ambition: to encourage and enable the emergence of French unicorns in eHealth and to democratize eHealth.

div.head: National perspective for Germany
div.p: Germany has the highest old age dependency ratio in the European Union now and in the foreseeable future. With roughly 82 million inhabitants Germany is the most populous country in the European Union. However, its fertility rate of 1.44 children per woman is one of the lowest in the world 24 . The population in some German regions, especially the former Communist East Germany, is undergoing a current decline and depopulation. The labor force potential, i.e. the number of people available to the labor market, has already reached its maximum of 45 million and is projected to linearly decrease by 400.000 people per annum. In light of these demographic trends, the German government reduced early retirement incentives and, in 2007, introduced a gradual increase of pension entitlement age from the age of 65 to 67 25 . The southern states however have net gain in population and Germany as the economic powerhouse of the EU is attracting immigrants overall.

The ageing population process in Germany poses many different challenges, and in particular the ones related to health and active living is not to be underestimated. Simply put the ageing population causes that more and more people will need help / assistance in their daily activities.

Senior citizens who spend long hours alone face the risk of not receiving assistance in case of an emergency (e.g. feeling sick, falling). This also creates a problem for their family members, restricting their possibilities of working or leaving home for a few hours. The economic factors also result in a lack of proper care, especially in peripheral areas, e.g. unemployment and resulting migrations, commuting. Statistics show that 1 in 3 people aged over 65 years fall at least once a year (70% of falls at home occur in the bathroom, where using a phone is limited), one third of them end up with hip injuries. In addition, 50% of senior citizens are unable to correctly dial the emergency number when distressed and 25% are unable to give precise personal data and address to the dispatcher. At the same time, there is insufficient care personnel to support families at the place of residence instead of using a nursing home. Nursing homes availability is significantly below needs -in some regions long waiting times can be observedand this type of residential care is the most expensive for public budgets. Remote domestic monitory for this increasing population often becomes the only viable solution. The solution is designated by "silver economy", which represents an opportunity for entrepreneurs who can develop a strong market of "silver" services and products.

These "silver products" should include smart housing and tele-care solutions, telemedicine solutions and remote monitoring devices. Main goal: to ensure that elderly/sick/disabled citizens can live safely in their own home as long as possible by providing care, assistance, and necessary services at home with the use of ITC.

With this proposal, we address many use cases directly targeting this market, some indirectly through the medical staff. The pertinent example of cadiovascular diseases is more relevant in this aging panorama. Heart diseases are the leading cause of death for both man and women of all ages. In particular, chronic atrial fibrillation in the current aging population is an evident problem, which will become a crisis in the next 5 to 10 years. Undetected cardiac issues due to the lack of post-hospitalization monitoring demands relevant innovations in healthcare. Telemedicine platforms and remote assistance devices are seen as the only solution towards mitigating current trends.

div.head: National perspective for Hungary
div.p: Since the early 1990s patients have a unique ID number linked to their digital medical records. In 2008 national health reform was carried out which included uploading medical records from the hospitals to a central governmentcontrolled server hosting health data. The largest IT development of the Hungarian healthcare has been started in 2015 in order to transform national healthcare system into eHealth system, which widely uses Information and Communication Technologies. As a result, all participants of medical treatment process (patients, doctors, pharmacists) becomes more and more 'digitalized' 26figure below.
