The new system is intended to allow continuous access and regular update of the health data. The main goal is to create the large Electronic Health Cooperation Service Space platform, which is able to provide the following: electronic patient summaries, patient privacy service, ePrescription, EHR-repository, scientific registry engine, eConsultation, eReferral, etc. The development of the Hungarian national eHealth system started at the end of 2014 and was being continued until 2015, the pilot system is tested during 2016 and 2017 and will go live in 2017-2018. The full budget of the development is close to HUF 10 Billion, which is EUR 32 Million. The interest to eHealth applications is increasing as well as investmens in their development.

div.head: National perspective for Israel
div.p: Israel's healthcare system is well-advanced by international standards. Israel is also known as a research and development hub for startups in the medical and biotech industry. Given the high level of healthcare and innovation, Israel's healthcare sector attracts technology companies and investors. The healthcare consumer market is relatively small with only 8.5 million people, but it presents opportunities for novel technologies and therapeutics. Israel is well advanced in the implementation of multifunctional, interoperable health IT systems, built around electronic medical records. Every Israeli resident holds a magnetic membership card they present at every point of service, thereby enabling the system to capture all of the members' transactions within the healthcare delivery system.

div.head: National perspective for Korea
div.p: South Korean healthcare system rated as the fourth most efficient healthcare system out of the 55 nations rated as of 2016. South Korean healthcare offers the choice of occidental medicine, or traditional oriental treatments, many of which have been extensively researched and developed alongside their modern counterparts. The country leads the world in the treatment of different diseases both in techniques and technology. The 5G eHealth project will surely enrich the Korean health care system. Using the facilities which are provided by the 5G eHealth project can solve the existing problems in health caring system in Korea. This project will also open the business opportunities for Korea. Korea will be able to export world best health system to other countries. Bringing 5G and e-health solutions in a same platform using the emerging wire and wireless (e.g., OCC) technologies for making a reliable, robust, fast, simple solution for patients.

div.head: National perspective for Spain
div.p: The development of 5G technology and its enablers are one of the key priority areas for the Spanish institutions for next years. These facts are reflected through different R&D programs pursued by the Spanish Government thanks to the support of R&D institutions like the Ministry of Energy, Tourism and the Digital Agenda (MINETAD) and Ministry of Economy and Competitivity (MINECO and its Centre for the Development of Industrial Technology (CDTI)) which drives short-term technological innovations. Health^5G project will contribute by creating new technological knowledge and applications oriented to eHealth market thanks to an extensive and cross-sectorial collaboration between different actors. In that sense, the national consortium will participate in the research and development of new 5G-enable technologies applied to eHealth solutions. Each of the partners that compose the Spanish consortium contributes as an agent of the value chain in the development of new technologies regarding the different salient features that provide the 5G technology for the eHealth sector.

Real-time communications ensuring high quality of service and zero latency is one of the main requirements in eHealth and it can be provided thanks to 5G technology. The data provided from the different medical sensors and devices needs to be injected to the 5G IoT platform. In this case, Televés will analyse, design and develop new 5G hardware and firmware to provide an ubiquous e-health solution in specific use case validation ecosystems, integrating information from different medical devices and providing the best technology combination to reach ehealth system optimization. To ensure the necessary voice and video communications, Quobis is going to contribute with the communication system for the 5G architecture developing the systems and interfaces required to integrate WebRTC-based applications that will empower instant messaging and collaborative communication between the medical devices. Introducing flexible networks is a key actor to ensure the quality for the different applications requirements, especially in case of emergency situations where the network traffic needs to guarantee the communications, Experis is going to develop the innovative network solution for the 5G-enabling virtualized network functions (NFV) and Software Defined Networking. This technology will allow to create a controller that will autonomously reroute the traffic depending on the emergency situation requirements. The increase in the number of devices and applications can create a security threat. To address the issue, Nunsys will participate assuring that 5G technologies and architectures are secured by default and supporting the analysis of abnormal behaviour patterns to guarantee availability, integrity and confidentiality. The analysis and validation from the use-case perspective will be contributed by Pulso. Pulso will focus this analysis on two main areas: how the developments of the project should be offered to the user's ecosystem (patients, caregivers, clinicians, etc) and on the other hand to define their integration roadmap into the existing Spanish eHealth infrastructures. UAB will participate in the project creating new knowledge in the development of Medical and eHealth devices & managing applications including the 5G bridging. This will encourage the transference of knowledge between industrial, SMEs and university partners in the project.

From TELEVES point of view 5G networks can be a revolution in the Health Market, proposals dealing elder care and providing a better datta collection and continuous evaluation of patients evolution is one of our main focus due to its innovation and strategic relevance.

div.head: National perspective for Sweden
div.p: Secure and simple access to relevant information about an individual is the key to Swedish national health-care and social services staff being able to offer high-quality services. Information is the key to empowerment and quality. To be practicable, however, the information needs to be structured, well defined and presented in different ways for different target groups. The main problem today in Sweden is not a lack of collected data but the fact that the information is not accessible or usable when it is most needed. There is a need for a holistic view of the various interventions an individual has undergone, as the care sector accommodates a broad spectrum of different activities, everything from primary care to elderly care and disability care. More and more people are nowadays looking for individual solutions to their problems, taking their own initiatives and making active choices. Citizens demand the same from the care sector as they do from other service providers in society, including a greater degree of insight, participation and self-determination. The healthcare and social services shall be able to offer services that are designed in accordance with the requirements and wishes of the individual and that use the Internet and social media as communication tools to a much greater degree than previously in order to increase both accessibility and user-friendliness. Many Swedish citizens have now health and social care needs that demand coordinated interventions from several different health authorities and practitioners.

The Government and the Swedish Association of Local Authorities and Regions want to support efforts to make use of the opportunities of digitization in social services and health care, and have now decided to endorse a common vision for eHealth up to 2025. For future work on eHealth, relevant actors in the social services and health care need a more long-term common approach. The vision is that by 2025, Sweden will be the best in the world at using the opportunities offered by digitization and eHealth to make it easier for people to achieve good and equal health and welfare. Sweden's biggest player in ICT -Ericssonnamed digital health as the number one trend in their "10 hot consumer trends 2017"-report. Frost & Sullivan predicts that "By 2025, HealthTech systems could be involved in everything from population health management, to digital avatars capable of answering specific patient queries."

The Health^5G project will contribute exactly with the technological advancements backed by pilot tests and demonstrators to ensure the smooth integration and access to health-care data and treatment at home, in hospital and in emergency situations. The project is aligned with the current national initiatives such as Embedded Sensor Systems for Health (ESS-H) and ecare@home that established as a nationally leading and an internationally renowned research centre for embedded sensor systems for health, and run at Mälardalen University together with industrial partners and healthcare providers. Quoting from Turkey's 2023 Health Vision Document, a number of goals stand out:a) Legislation and implementation for protection of personal data, b) Healthcare at home will be made universal, c) Smart diagnosis algorithms will be put in place, d) Patient-specific healthcare treatment will be initiated and made universal.

Turkey has a great potential for telemedicine, teleconsultation, remote monitoring, emergency services on eHealth with its growing population and economy. Turkey started its reform program in eHealth in order to provide more health services to all the citizens, especially having difficulties when accessing these services in rural remote parts in 1997. Since the year 2003, these efforts gained more support as digital transformation in health sector deemed inevitable as government wanted to build a central electronics platform to manage all the medical bills, appointments, medicine and hospital records and allocated more funds in spite of the tehnological, organizational and financial problems. Improvements in internet speed, bandwidth, and availibility in the last couple of decades provide more means to achieve this goal. The project outcomes in the form of medical devices and ehealth services combined with latest state-of-the-art 5G telecommunication capabilities aligned with Turkish governmental goals for health, will offer appealing opportunities in telecommunication, public health, and home appliances markets. The partnerships developed among the european and turkish consortium in this project will openup new possibilities for colloboration on health and telecommunication, not only providing better health services for the turkish citizens, and but also efficieny in governmental spending by reducing travel, elderly and patient monitoring costs. It is also anticipated that, diagnoses accury will increase as more data will be available to the medical personel while patients at the remote rural places will have more medical personel available to them as they can connect to the urban hospitals for a second opinion on their medical problems. Furthermore, low latency, reliable and high performance ehealth applications enabled by 5G, combining Internet of Things, telecommunication, teleconsultation and emergency services will produce more accurate and agile treatment of elderly and patients with an increased life quality and life expectancy. Citizens will be living healthier lives, health insitutions, hospitals, telecommunication and consumer electronics companies will enlarge their products range with new eHealth services and devices, and goverment will save more on health sector spending.due to research, development and implementation of the innovative health services developed in this project.

div.head: National perspective for Ukraine
div.p: According to Presidential Reform Program, the reform of the healthcare system and, in particular, the development of telemedicine is a primary task up to 2020. The convergence between wireless communication technologies and healthcare devices and between health and social care is creating new thriving businesses all over. Redesigning the delivery of care using 5G capabilities inside and outside the hospital are highly promising markets.

div.head: National perspective for Finland
div.p: In a national perspective being in the forefront of this development naturally means that Finland gains several business advantages given that the technological achievements are followed by consecutive marketing and sales initiatives. Using Finland as a testbed and proof of concept for the 5G-E-health will significantly help export sales to rest of Europe and the world.

Finland national strategy envisions innovative healthtech solutions as one of main Finnish export industry with high potential for future growth (see Figure below). The identified health care assets combine Finnish strengths in medical research, health technology, health data and clinical co-creation. The project's focus is in line with focus areas identified on national level and include hospital care redefinition, elderly care, etc. Finland is actively participating 5G standardization works with health applications identified as one of main focus areas for 5G. Finland has good footprint and multiple local initiatives, involving SMEs27 28 29 .

div.head: National perspective for France
div.p: The importance of any system is shown by its effective used, however in case of health care system it becomes vital to provide better quality and safer health care centre. The modernization of health care system, which consists of electronics information and communication technology will benefit patients, healthcare professionals and industry, as they open new opportunities for clinical, research, education, and easy administration. The e-Health care market in Health^5G project is completely aligned with the national perspectives and objectives will help the country to position its leadership in the market. Furthermore, the French landscape is characterized by a distortion between an effective leadership in security and system on chip industries, and a slow adoption of e-services, particularly from the public sector compared to Nordic countries and the US. As a matter of consequence, France is mainly an exporter of key enabling technologies for e-services to a number of neighbour countries, which have more aggressive digitalization policies or lower constraint from the legacy. The Billentis survey on February 2015 places France in an average position in a world dominated by Scandinavian & Baltic Countries, Mexico, Brazil, and Chile.

The French Government is aware of the health digitalization, the eHealth, and the PHS (Personal Health System) and the RMT (Remote Patient Monitoring and Treatment) concepts which mean a cost decrease and a better patient control and has started investing on it. European Commission predicts that telemedicine global market will reach 27300 million euros in 2016, and will continue to grow. In this perspective, the Health^5G project is completely in line with the strategic initiatives at national level and will contribute to consolidate eHealth and its market in France. The active participation of industrial partner, SME, academic, and especially French hospital into Health^5G will reinforce the European experimentation for future concrete deployments.

div.head: National perspective for Germany
div.p: The described problem of the aging population in Germany in point 1.3.4, and the face of the European challenge it presents, also offers opportunities to address these issues in due time, with economically viable solutions. CVDs in particular are the group of diseases that most affect the world population, and carries the largest death count for the elderly population. Solutions to address these issues and benefit patients with cardiology diseases and facilitate the interaction with the respective doctors are an increasing relevant business opportunity. Current developments by one the consortium members in Germany, and one of the presented Use-Cases directly deals with this issue and aims to develop a solution that will help the patient to control its cardiac problem in an autonomously and active way. The business opportunities lay primarily with the cardiology institutions that will be able to provide a better treatment to their growing list of patients. According the European cardiovascular disease statistics is possible to verify that the number of surgical procedures is very large and is growing and consequently we have a potential target market to explore. In 2014 there were over 430,000 patients [over 55] with heart failure in EU.

The mentioned chronic cardiac patients are a very large market, with huge growth potential. For the companies that supply medical hardware, software and maintenance in this field will become dominant in the future of healthcare. New technological opportunities presented by mobile networks further provide opportunities for both better and safer medical products, as well as new business model opportunities not yet available for medical products. The technological development foreseen in this proposal goes beyond the detailed use cases, and opens new doors to new ideas, applications and scientific progresses that will not only turn to be economically valuable, but also scientific and human valuable.

The economic impact on health in Germany is also evident since providing such innovative solutions to the market we will improve not only patient treatment and quality-of-life, but also avoids cardiovascular complications that get progressively worse until it is too late, and also reduces costs due to unnecessary hospitalization, through remote monitoring. During this project the partner Inova DE will involve the Medical University of Heidelberg to evaluate the quality of developed solution for cardiology and the easiness of integrating into the existing clinical workflow of such mobile remote monitoring devices. This study carries heavy impact on the business aspect of such innovations, as it directly reflects the market expectations and future uptake.

div.head: National perspective for Hungary
div.p: Within the e-health providing in Hungary, there is health app aimed at improving public health and supporting people with chronic diseases by providing a living connection between the health professionals and the patients. The free app is running with 20 thousand users who have got an access to disease information, one's doctor and personal health records. Patients can upload information such as details about their diet, weight, blood pressure, glucose levels, exercise and conditions such as pregnancy. The app provides an encyclopedia of health information and advice tailored to the user and has drug finder and pill reminder functions. There is 75% of household with broadband Internet access in Hungary and 80% of Hungarian population is using the Internet. Doctors' digitizing process is developing. In 2015 there were 13% of doctors who had their own website, 49% who were using IT for communication with patients, which is 21% more than in 2013, and 61% who is a member of health portal.

div.head: National perspective for Israel
div.p: For cost-saving products and for products that help patients monitor their health at home. Wound care, advanced diagnostics and minimally invasive procedures continue to be a high priority in the public healthcare market. Israel has an excellent digital health tech base and is a world leader in mobile and E-health implementations. Opportunities exist however, in further advancing drug monitoring and disease surveillance. Other best sales prospects include minimally invasive surgical instruments and technologies that are integrated with imaging capabilities, cardiology equipment, equipment and supplies for plastic surgery, smart implants, dental instruments, equipment and technologies for pain management, physiotherapy, ozone & oxygen therapy, OR equipment, cost-saving single use products, point of care diagnostic kits and wound management technologies. Awareness for preventive medicine and acceptance of diagnostic procedures into the reimbursement list opened the market to advanced diagnostic procedures. This shift includes early detection of breast and colon cancer and a set of standard, age-based diagnostic procedures. Wound care continues to be a high priority in preventive care. In addition, a well-developed private sector healthcare in the areas of dental, eye laser surgery and plastic/aesthetic surgery keep up the demand for advanced medical instruments and appliances. See, also 31 .

div.head: National perspective for Korea
div.p: The South Korean healthcare system is run by the Ministry of Health and Welfare and is free to all citizens at the point of delivery. It maintains a universal healthcare system that is rated as the fourth most efficient healthcare system out of the 55 nations rated as of 2016. The system is funded by a compulsory National Health Insurance Scheme that covers 97% of the population. South Korean healthcare offers the choice of occidental medicine, or traditional oriental treatments, many of which have been extensively researched and developed alongside their modern counterparts. The country leads the world in the treatment of skin diseases, both in techniques and technology. Its healthcare security system has three arms: The National Health Insurance Program, Medical Aid Program, and Long-term Care Insurance Program. Total expenditure on health is 7.4% of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) (2014). Total expenditure on health per capita (2014) is $2.531. It has among the lowest HIV/AIDS adult prevalence rate in the world, with just 0.1% of the population being infected. The number of hospital beds per 1000 population is 10. 94% of hospitals (88% of beds) are privately owned 30 of the 43 tertiary hospitals are run by private universities, and 10 more are run by publicly owned universities. The number of primary care doctors in cities is 37.3% higher than rural areas, and the problem is growing because younger physicians are choosing to practice in the cities. Due to medical profit maximization strategies, most private medical facilities are located in urban areas, and 92.1% of physicians and 90.8% of hospital beds are in urban areas, while 79.7% of the population lives in urban areas. Additionally, there are three structural problems in the Korean health care system: 1) medical specialists make up more than 80% of practicing medical doctors in Korea. 2) the private medical care sector currently consumes about 90% of total health care resources, particularly in terms of hospital beds. 3) pharmaceutical expenditures have consumed about 30% of total health expenditures. Using the facilities which is provided by the 5G, e-health can solve the existing problems.

div.head: National perspective for Spain
div.p: The For example, via the Swedish health start-up KRY, which developed the digital appointment technology, some parts of the country have trial digital appointments, allowing patients to have a first consultation via an app rather than forcing them to travel to a physical doctor's office and wait in line. The solution depends in part on Sweden's BankID system, originally developed to facilitate secure transactions for online banking. Another e-health innovation being tested in Stockholm allows stroke patients to conduct therapy sessions at a distance from their own homes, rather than requiring them to remain in hospital for the duration of their therapy. It uses motion sensor technology and a screen that allows for two-way communications with a physical therapist sitting in a remote office.

Despite these and other solutions that can streamline data processing, treatments, and hospital management, Sweden has yet to cement its position as a true e-health leader, by implementing systems that can facilitate coordination and patient information flow. A common IT infrastructure would bring savings and improve patient satisfaction by making it easier to make sense of the massive amounts of data currently collected in the healthcare system. The "information scarcity" makes it impossible to map the data and create systems that are self-learning and which could ultimately lead to better, faster diagnoses, especially when it comes to rare diseases that involve consultations with multiple specialists before the correct diagnosis can be made. To maximize the benefits that Big Data and artificial intelligence can bring to the healthcare industry, Sweden needs a system where all the data and the insights gained from hospitals and clinics across the country are shared from the start, which creates tremendous business opportunities based on the Health^5G results.

div.head: National perspective for Turkey
div.p: Turkish Ministry of Health announced yearly governmental budget for health is around 65 billion TL, with a 10 billion increase compared to that of previous year. This budget mainly reserved for covering costs for emergency services, public health sector, hospitalization, and medical devices and medicine. Population of Turkey rises and expected to increase in upcoming years. Furthermore the aging pyramid suggests that the senior citizens with increased life expectancy will account for %10 of the population in 2020s, approximately %5 higher than compared to 20 years earlier. With these figures at hand, Turkish health expenditure is expected to grow. Since 2003, Turkish ministry of health focuses on e-health sector, with special attention to telemedicine and teleconsultation services and connecting the rural parts of the country with the modern developed urban institutions. Also Turkish ministry of health focuses on building a central electronic platform to manage all the medical bills, prescriptions, medications across the country. Medical equipment market in Turkey is around 3 billion euros with medical equipment largely imported from foreign countries. In Turkey, E-health sector is expected to make 200 million euros yearly in revenue in 2020, where revenue figures rises with an annual grow rate of %18. Market analysis has shown that global home healthcare market size is about 210 billion euros, whereas global health IT market is around 40 billion euros with similar yearly growth rates of %10. Turkey is one of the very populated countries in Europe which can enjoy the benefits of growing eHealth industry in terms of many different aspects: Improving health services, reducing costs and increasing the efficiency, lowering health costs of dependent people and the elderly and encouraging and supporting industries which are able to offer a competitive product on e-health. Next generation mobile technology (5G) will provide capabilities to provide low latency, reliable and high performance applications in health sector combining Internet of Things, telemedicine, and teleconsultation services which are primarily important for Turkish ministry of Health in order to connect individuals on remote parts of the country to the centralized urban hospitals for health services. To sum up, this project will provide a strong insight about necessary and possible improvements in the eHealth industry to Turkish market.

div.head: National perspective for Ukraine
div.p: The healthcare is a continuously developing area in Ukraine administered by The Ministry of Healthcare. In 2017 there were allocated 62 billion of Hryvnas and it is 10% more than in 2015 and 8% more than in 2016. At the moment the main focus of the Ukrainian healthcare system is on rural medicine. There are 13 million of Ukrainians, which is 13% of Ukrainian population, who live in the rural area, and an issue of providing them with high-qualified medical support is the main priority for the Ministry of Healthcare. For now, rural area provision of highly tailored doctors is not sufficient, and so implementation of telemedicine is considered as one of the key solutions. In September 2017 the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine registered a draft on medical care system in the rural area. In particular, telemedicine and eHealth system are being introduced as key services for an instantaneous and high-qualified medical aid for Ukrainian villagers. Demo-version of the first eHealth system in Ukraine has been launched in July 2017. The developers predict that the system will be fully-functioned allowing patients to use all the medical services from any spot in Ukraine.

div.head: Relevance to Celtic-Plus
div.p: The focus of Celtic-Plus is in telecommunications, ICT, well-being of the society and security. In addition Celtic-Plus aims to strengthen the European industry. Health^5G's relevance to Celtic-plus is easy to see, as the aim is to utilize and develop telecommunication (5G, heterogeneous networks, IoT), and ICT (health services, data analysis etc), and to aim with these developments to enhance the health care services in Europe. During the project, different types of industry partners will be able to innovate new products and services, and study and pilot how their products and services can be enhanced and brought to international markets.
Key topics related to Health^5G -project are: network capacity, mobility, security, robustness, 5G, Smart Cities, Smart Homes, e-health, big data, Internet of Things and privacy.

div.head: Major visible results, products
div.p: The main objective of the project is to investigate the 5G technology as an enabler for new health and care services, and give insights about the needed technological developments, as well as indications about the impact on all aspects, including service, technology and business. The main results will be:

-Novel services for supporting healthcare, based on capabilities that are needed, but cannot be achieved without the novel characteristics of 5G. The models for these services will result by describing in detail possible use cases as a starting point, developing the necessary technology, so that there can be realistic tests and pilots conducted and providing full assessment. Important aspects such as security mechanisms for medical data protection will play a role. Validation and analysis of the possible impacts will indicate how these services will lead to lower healthcare costs, efficient service delivery, better and more effective healthcare, equal health services for all and better quality of life for the patients and citizens, as well as better quality of life at work for the healthcare professionals. -New business opportunities for companies, who will be able to utilise the 5G technology to offer their clients new products and services. 5G presents also the opportunity for new ways of connectivity of devices and services and relevant platforms. This hides the potential for creating business ecosystems around a specific case, which will support SMEs in conceiving new business opportunities together with other companies, and allow them to enter markets that until now have been difficult for them. -Effective utilisation of 5G capabilities, which can be well studied while piloting the new services. The project will conduct an exhaustive research about how each new thing that 5G brings can be used in eHealth. The research will give results about the 5G connectivity of medical devices and sensors, of IoT ecosystems, and 5G gateways, through concrete demos (3 iterations). Architecture addressing eHealth, with functional components therein, interfaces, used / developed protocols, and integration of Network Virtualization and Edge Computing will be developed. Recommendations and visions about the near future that will set out the path for more innovations will be produced. -In this way, the project will also provide scientific contributions, but publishing and sharing the gained knowledge about the use of 5G in eHealth.

div.head: Contribution to Standards
div.p: The contribution in the standardization work in this project will happen by active and direct contributing to standards, as well as developing new 5G and eHealth technology following and complying with relevant existing standards. Active contributions by the relevant partners will be made e.g. to 3GPP ongoing tasks for 5G and LTE Enhancements. Relevant standardization activities for eHealth applications like low latency LTE (LTE sTTI in 3GPP Release 14), ultra reliable low latency communication (LTE URLLC in Release 15) and 5G New Radio URLLC (Release-15 and 16) will be taken into account for the prototype development within eHealth^5G WP4. Through the use cases and pilots, recommendations will be done about needed enhancements for 4G/5G standards.

Enhancements and modifications of the relevant ONF standards will be proposed. Contributions will also be made to the IEEE standardization activities, such as to the group IEEE 802.15.7m Optical Wireless Communications, which is developing the current IEEE 802.15.7 specification, as well as to standardization groups in the medical domain, and particularly HL7. New OCC functionalities are being proposed to ISO TC WG 16. Standardization on the requirements and architecture for the 5G-based eHealth services in standard developing organizations (SDOs) such as ITU-T. Standardisation activities of the application of CRISP-DM principles on e-Health data, including standards regarding access to data sources, e-Health specific data cleaning, data transformation and data anonymization will also be done. Existing 3GPP recommendations will be used for the design of a WebRTC-based platform. The ETSI activities (IEEE 802.1, PHY, MAC for eHealth) will brought to focus during the use cases, and the ETSI TC CYBER standards will be followed, contributing to General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). The devices used by some of the partners are already comply with IEEE11073/X73, IHE and Continua protocols, and have Bluetooth, ZigBee, Wifi and USB capabilities. IEC technical committees and European Technology Platforms like NEM and NESSI are being followed. Details about how each partner will contribute to or follow standardization activities are given in Appendix.

In order to secure the data circulating in the medical IoT environment, this task concentrates on the security aspects of IoT. Integration and implementation of these new security mechanism and protocols in existing medical platforms will be carried out here and validated with actual devices. Also, the different communication option and performance according to the usage of the medical/health device (indoor, small distance, macro) and the impact of the related RF characteristics in their certification requirements will be tackled. Finally, it amis to analyse 5G-networks and hardware chip enablers in the new ecosystem. As a result, This task will provide the base hardware support to deploy the 5G networks in the e-health perspective. T4.1 will be connected to the development and results of Tasks T2.2 and all tasks from WP3 and its results will affect all other tasks in WP4 and WP5. The main results expected for T4.1 will be the implementation model for the new 5G medical device platforms for both the specific embedded platforms (including the sensor and actuator devices) and 5G communications modules. The integration of 5G capacity in eHealth devices enablers provides the base hardware/firmware support to deploy the 5G networks in the e-health perspective with a device that provides hight bit rate and low jitter. An example of medical information is a real time ECG evaluation in movement in an ambulance. Specifically, a new "5G eHealth Device Concentrator" will allow the monitoring in real time of critical services in an ubiquous e-health solution, for that is required extremely wide bandwidth and QoS; as mentioned in the example (ECG). The developed platforms and examples will be used in WP5. The main objectives of this task are to:

 Develop novel design methods to build new 5G eHealth applications and their integration to health ecosystems, based on the use cases and requirements, as a composition of interoperable microservices, deployed in IoT, MEC devices and the cloud.  Develop novel model-based testing methods for IoT-based medical applications built as a composition of microservices, including testing of functional and non-functional properties, including robustness and security. The activity of this task will begin with a study on the state-of-the-art in terms of both research approaches and existing (commercial and/or open source) software solutions and tools in the context of connected eHealth applications and services. Within this task, relevant existing technologies will be identified. We will examine the outcome of WP2 with respect to the requirements for use case and architectural specifications, in order to identify how the shift to 5G will affect the development of eHealth applications and services. Hence, the methodology of this task is exploratory. More specifically, our focus will be on composing disjoint (micro)services processing information from IoT, MEC devices and the cloud technologies. The main results for T4.2 will be new design and testing methods supporting the development of new innovative eHealth services and applications. These will be integrated in WP5. The main objectives of this task are as follows:

-Design advanced data (pre) processing modules for eHealth type of data -Implement solutions for data analysis by using machine learning and data mining solutions -Development of mobile applications for patients having medical treatment at home; the applications are based on processing of data collected by a patient; the health status prediction is obtained by using data analysis.

This task will study the available solutions for data management and analysis and later on, it provides specific algorithms and methods based on the existing solutions. The main outcome of this activity is methods to process and analyse the available data in the project in order to conduct different defined experiments in the project objectives and usecases. This task will study and implement selected eHealth services or their parts into a distributed cloud environment. The task will consider especially localized services or services requiring low latency response or increased security through local processing of the collected health and medical data. The task will study service architectures for distributed computing and their application in the context of selected eHealth^5G services. Actual MEC or fog computing applications will be designed and developed according to the cloud platform specification defined in Task 3.3. The resulting MEC and fog applications will be integrated into the distributed cloud infrastructure for experimental evaluation in WP5. The task will provide the MEC/fog components (report and software) for selected eHealth^5G services. The components will be integrated into the pilot systems in WP5. The aim of WP5 is to develop a series of trials and pilots in real scenarios recreating different use cases to validate the results of the project and the fulfilment of KPIs. In task 5.1, the demonstrators and the pilots will be defined to make a realistic evaluation of the objectives. The feedback received from these tasks will allow to develop, in Task 5.4, the trials and pilots in real scenarios that will generate the final project results ensuring the full coverage of the system developed. This mean that we would need to create a plan for the integration in advance and work closely with T5.1 on the definitions of the demonstrations and their pilots. div.head: PROJECT MANAGEMENT
div.p: The management of the project encompasses both the project coordination and administration (general administration, contractual issues, interfacing with Celtic office and other bodies, etc.) and the technical coordination (Follow-up of the work done in the WPs, technical issues solving, etc.).

The Health 5G project will be managed by a Project Coordination Committee (PCC). PCC members will be Work Package Leaders plus one representative of each partner for partners who do not lead any Work Package. The PCC will be chaired by the Project Coordinator who will be helped by the Technical Coordinator. The PCC will review the progress of the work and take the appropriate decisions in case of technical problems or conflicts inside the Consortium. The PCC will meet periodically (three times per year) or exceptionally if requested. Teleconferences may replace some physical meetings. In case of a serious problem, a Task force may be initiated by the PCC to solve it. The task force will be composed of partners' employees meeting the skills identified by the PCC to solve the problem.

The Project Coordinator represents the project and the Consortium. This person reports to CELTIC officials and monitors overall consortium activity and performance. He/she promotes the project by ensuring its visibility and facilitates the dissemination of project results in the relevant national and international forums.

The Technical Coordinator is in charge to coordinate and keep the consistency between the work packages. This person ensures the accomplishment of the technical and business objectives of the project and assists the Project Coordinator when required.

The Work Package Leaders ensure the correct execution of the Work Package they are responsible for, according to the planning agreed at the beginning of the project and regularly reviewed by the PCC. Each Work Package Leader is responsible for the correct delivery (quality and punctuality) of the deliverables produced within his Work Package.

div.head: Decision making process and conflict resolution
div.p: Voting shall be the method to solve conflicts and take decisions in the project. In the Project Coordination Committee, decisions will be adopted by majority. Each PCC member will have 1 vote. In case of tie, the Project Coordinator will have the casting vote. Inside the Work Package Teams, decisions and conflicts will be solved by majority as well. Each member (person) of the team shall have 1 vote. In case of tie, or if no solution is found, decision shall be taken by the Project Coordination Committee.

His skills include software engineering and object oriented design, project management using agile methodologies (scrum). He develops in Java, C# and SQL and uses GiT and SVN. Prior to S-Labs, he worked in Turkey's leading map provider company as R&D lead and published 3 papers and took 2 patents while actively developing the ongoing vehicle tracking software.His research focuses on privacy preserving data publishing in data mining and data analytics. He is active reviewer in many conferences and journals of IEEE. He currently serves as team lead at S-Labs SemperTech in Istanbul. He worked as research and teaching assistant for 6 years at Sabancı University, Istanbul. During his studies he has also worked as a freelance developer on many mobile applications and web projects. His skills include software engineering, object oriented design and mobile design. He develops in Java, C++, Objective-C, Swift, PHP and SQL and uses GiT and SVN. His research focuses on privacy preserving data publishing in data mining, concentrating mostly on social media data. He currently serves as team lead at S-Labs SemperTech in Istanbul.

div.head: Turkcell Teknoloji
div.p: Company profile: Turkcell, founded and headquartered in Turkey, is a converged communication and digital services player that serves with customers with voice, data, TV and value-added consumer and enterprise services on mobile and fixed networks. BiP, Turkcell TV+, fizy, lifebox are among the over-the-top (OTT) apps offered by Turkcell. Turkcell has more than 50M subscribers in 9 different countries. In Turkey alone, Turkcell is the leading mobile operator with more than 33M subscribers. Turkcell Technology, a Turkcell subsidiary, is among Turkey's leading R&D and innovation companies with about 1000 employees. Turkcell is also an active partner at Next Generation Mobile Networks (NGMN) leading 5G test efforts.

Role in the project: Turkcell contributes research expertise in areas including (but not limited to) the following: 5G, Network Slicing, Cellular networks, Network Architecture, Mobile Edge Computing, SDN, NFV, Machine Learning, Big Data technologies, IoT, Small cells.

div.head: Experts involved:
div.p: Dr. Salih Ergüt (male) has more than 15 years of experience in the telecommunication domain in academia and industry. He has worked for vendor and operator companies in the sector including Ericsson Wireless (San Diego, CA), Ericsson Silicon Valley, Aware (Boston, MA), Nextwave (San Diego, CA), Turk Telekom Group (Istanbul, Turkey) and is currently working at Turkcell 5G R&D team in Istanbul, Turkey. His research interests include wireless communications, machine learning, big data technologies, 5G technologies, SDN, NFV, and IoT.

Dr. Nazli Guney (female) is a researcher at Turkcell Technologies and acts as an R&D project coordinator with a special focus on future 5G networks, capitalizing on her previous experience related to small cell (formerly known as femtocell) and software-defined networking (SDN) technologies, for which she has been granted two US patents. Dr. Guney received her B.S.

(with high honors), M.S. and PhD degrees in electrical and electronics engineering from Bogazici University, Istanbul, Turkey, in 2001, 2003, and 2009, respectively, being a research assistant during the years 2001-2009 at the same university. Her business acumen and special interest in go-to-market strategies for new product development activities led her to receive an Executive MBA degree in 2014, also from Bogazici University, where she ranked first in her class.

While her academic research comprises wavelet-based signal processing, planar object recognition and various aspects of wireless communications ranging from ultra-wideband transceiver design to information theoretical calculation of achievable rates in realistic environments, her industrial efforts have been centered on 4G and beyond mobile communication systems as well as Internet of Things (IoT).

div.head: Institut Mines Telecom
div.p: Company profile: Institut Mines-Télécom is a public institution dedicated to higher education, research and innovation in the engineering and digital fields. It is made up of 10 Mines and Télécom "grandes écoles", under the aegis of the Minister of Industry and also it includes five centres of excellence across the country (http://www.mines-telecom.fr/en_accueil.html). IMT is a centre of higher education and research in telecommunications providing graduate programs in engineering and management of telecommunications services and networks. The institute includes more than 170 full time researchers, excluding adjunct professors and visiting lecturers, from both industry and academic institutions who contribute their experience and expertise in the field of telecommunications systems and networks. Telecom SudParis (TSP) is a member of the Association of Graduate Schools and the European Foundation for Management Development.

The Service Architecture Lab (http://servicearchitecture.wp.tem-tsp.eu/) is a leading research group with a focus on Future Services. The team works in collaboration with key players from industry and academia around the world. The major areas of expertise are in Service Architecture, Online Social Networks, and Internet of Things. Beyond academic research, the team shares and disseminates its results through active cooperation with leaders from the communications industry. The laboratory is one of the few academic groups that is contributing to standardisation at IETF, IRTF, oneM2M and ITU-T, and is also heavily involved in collaborative research through national and European projects (H2020, FP7, ITEA2, CELTIC, ANR).

Data collection (Social networks, Web sources and IoT) and data management, including data analysis for different aspects such as recommendations and predictions, constitutes one of our main areas of expertise in the field. The Service Architecture Lab has developed a number of mechanisms to deal with these issues using different approaches both based on heuristics and Artificial Intelligence techniques.

Role in the project: IMT will contribute on the data collection, data (pre)processing and data analysis activities of the project. In addition IMT will lead the dissemination activities in the project.

div.head: Experts involved:
div.p: Prof. Noel Crespi (noel.crespi@mines-telecom.fr) is the head of the Service Architecture Laboratory. He coordinates the standardisation activities for Institut Mines-Telecom, Telecom SudParis at ETSI, 3GPP, ITU-T and oneM2M. He and his team actively participate and have participated in a number of EU projects (FP7 eCOUSIN, H2020 re-THINK, ITEA CAP, SEAS, TWIRL, SITAC, Web of Objects, ICARE, Do It Yourself, Expeshare, CELTIC SERVERY...). He is also an adjunct professor at Concordia University (Canada) as well as adjunct professor at KAIST (Korea), and is on the 4-person Scientific Advisory Board of FTW (Austria). He previously worked from 1993 in CLIP, Bouygues Telecom and then France Telecom R&D in 1995, and joined Nortel Networks as Telephony Program leader in 1999. His current research interests are in Service Architectures, Communication Services, P2P Social Networks, and Internet of Things/Services. He is the author/co-author of more than 300 papers and contributions in standardisation.

Dr. Reza Farahbakhsh (reza.farahbakhsh@it-sudparis.eu) is a postdoctoral researcher at the Institut Mines-Telecom, Telecom SudParis (Service Architecture Lab). His research interests are focused on Online Social Networks, Peer-to-Peer System, BigData Analysis, Measurement, etc. He is actively involved in a number of European projects (FP7 eCOUSIN, ITEA2 TWIRL, CelticPlus Convince, etc.) and he is the main contact of IMT-TSP in the proposal preparation of several new projects (H2020, ITEA3, CelticPlus, ANR). He is co-author of more than 20 papers in top venues such as IEEE Communication magazine, IEEE Network Magazine, IEEE P2P, etc.

div.head: Green communications
div.p: Company profile: Green Communications is an innovative SME with a unique expertise in autonomous networks and local Internet. Its products are based on ad hoc, Mesh, and D2D technologies and carry a complete TCIP/IP and provides Participatory Internet (GreenPI) solutions for large public venues, public safety, and connection to the Internet of things. Green PI consists in autonomous and embedded mesh open routers offering local services and content. Green IP is a solution able to connect high-density areas, mobile units at a lower cost, things from different worlds like medical, smart cities, stadium, etc. Green Communications is the result of 10 years of research and provides today unique performances such as video conferencing over 30 WiFi hops. Green Communications' work is European widely recognised, the company participates in many conferences and competitions.

div.head: Role in the project:
div.p: Green will participate in WP2, AM3, WP5, and WP6. Green will be involved in a quite large number of tasks in order to add some glu between the tasks. Main participation will be in the connexion of medical things in WP3 and in the deployment defined in WP5.

div.head: Khaldoun Al Agha
div.p: Co-Founder, President and CEO of Green Communications Representative Officer of Paris-Sud University Khaldoun Al Agha is a former Professor at Paris-Sud University where he directed the Networking group at LRI (Research Laboratory in Computer Science) and the Master Degree in Computer science. He was the journals and conferences. Khaldoun Al Agha is a co-founder of EIT Digital. From 2010 to 2013, he directed the action line Digital Cities. In 2010, Khaldoun Al Agha co-created the KIC, EIT's Knowledge and Innovation Communities that aim to bring European education and research to innovation and value creation. The KICs started its mission in 2010 with a budget of 15 M€ and achieved a budget of 90 M€ in 2015..

div.head: Ignacy Gawedzki
div.p: Head of R&D at Green Communications Ignacy Gawedzki graduated from a Ph.D. in Computer Science at University of Paris XI in 2008 and from an Engineering Degree at EPITA in 2003.

div.head: Guy Pujolle
div.p: Guy Pujolle is a co-founder of Green Communications. He is also a Professor at Pierre et Marie Curie University -Paris 6. Guy Pujolle is a pioneer in high-speed networking having led the development of the first Gbit/s network to be tested in 1980. He was at the origin of several inventions and important patents like DPI, Wi-Fi controller, virtual networks, and morphware networks.

div.head: UPEC
div.p: Company profile: University of Paris-Est Créteil (UPEC) Val de Marne is a public university devoted to high level education and research excellence in engineering and medicine. The participation of the UPEC in this project will be carried out by the Image, Signal and Complex Systems (LiSSi) laboratory. LISSI develops methods and algorithms for modelling, analysis and control of networks and complex systems. Application fields are wired and wireless networks, e-Health, large ubiquitous robots, large scale enterprises, pervasive and distributed systems, autonomic and soft computing. Currently, the LISSI Lab counts around 71 members (including 8 professors, 30 associate professors, 6 research assistants and 28 PhD Students).

Role in the project: LiSSI Laboratory, the UPEC team involved in this project, has large expertise in those fields addressed in the proposal. This research has resulted in several publications in international journals or conference proceedings. LISSI has conducted several R&D projects mainly funded by European, national and regional R&D programs (FUI and ANR). The staff continuously collaborates with industrial and academic partners in various projects funded by FUI, Eureka and FP7 (ANSO, MDI, LEONARDO DA VINCI program SICINE project, ITEA2 SemBySem, ITEA2 Multipol WebOfObjects, IPNQSIS, TILAS, MedicalProx, POQEMON and NOTTS projects) covers topics such as QoS and QoE intelligent paradigms in wired and wireless areas. Research activities in software engineering (service based architectures, context-aware agent middleware, Intelligent Agents Platform for dynamic workflow and context-aware applications) are also developed. Since last 10 years, LiSSi has been focused on adaptive and autonomous control mechanisms for improving the Quality of Experience. In particular, our works is dedicated to a particular use cases, namely the ICT health as a part of a new paradigm called the Internet of Things for E-health over 5G networks. The LISSI team has set up a "living lab" consists of a set of communicating sensors (fixed and mobile) and physiological sensors to simulate a hospital environment. In addition, new curricula degrees dedicated to E-Health and networks are created by the team involved in this project: the first professional license and the first engineering degree dedicated to ICT-Health in France. All these curricula can be used in the dissemination activities of the project Experts involved:

Prof. Abdelhamid Mellouk (UPEC Full Professor), received the engineer degree in computer network engineering, the D.E.A. and Ph.D. degrees in computer science from the University of Paris Sud (ex. Paris11University), Orsay, France, and the D.Sc. (Habilitation) diploma from the University Paris Est Creteil (UPEC, ex. Paris 12 University), France. He is currently a full professor with UPEC, Networks & Telecommunications Department and LiSSi Laboratory, France. Founder of the Network Control Research activity with extensive international academic and industrial collaborations, his general area of research focus on computer networks, including adaptive real-time bio-inspired control mechanisms for high-speed dynamic wired/wireless networking with the objective to maintain acceptable quality of service/quality of experience for added value services dedicated to several domains such as ICT-Health. Prof. Mellouk has held several national and international offices, including leadership positions in the IEEE Communications Society Technical Committees. He has published/coordinated eight books, 3 lecture notes and several refereed international publications in journals, conferences, and books, in addition to numerous keynotes and plenary talks in flagship venues. He serves on the Editorial Boards or as Associate Editor for several journals, and he is chairing or has chaired (or co-chaired) some of the top international conferences and symposia (ICC, GlobeCom, VTC, etc.).

div.head: CEpiA
div.p: Company profile: CHU Mondor -CEpiA (Clinical Epidemiology and Ageing, EA7376; dir. Pr S Bastuji-Garin) is a research team focusing on developing geriatric clinical epidemiology and studies aimed at improving understanding of the ageing processes leading to frailty, both at the hospital level and in primary care setting. CEpiA is a multidisciplinary research team that gathers the complementary capabilities of epidemiologists (4), biostatisticians and data managers (4), geriatricians (5) and general practitioners (6) involved in both academic primary care research and clinical practice in the field. CHU Mondor (UPEC, CEpiA) has gained an expertise in handling large scale long-term follow-up cohorts (ELCAPA cohort, N=2200 older cancer patients enrolled; SUCCEED study >700 patients aged over 50 years enrolled), in building of predictive models based on clinic-biological markers and in analysing large databases such as the French claims database linked to hospital discharge database in geriatric setting. Relevant key achievements for the team include the first international trial on the impact of comprehensive geriatric assessment (CGA) on changing therapeutic decision in older cancer patients (EGeSOR), and a recent national public grant achieved for conducting a large multi-arm cluster randomized trial to assess the efficacy of CGA tailored for primary care applied by GPs and/or trained nurses (CEpiA study).

Role in the project: CHU Mondor (UPEC, CEpiA) will mainly participate in WP2 and WP5 by defining a specific use case for the care and management of older patients in hospital and primary care, then demonstrating in real-life setting the clinical and socioeconomic utility of the platform and the e-health solutions developed.

div.head: Experts involved:
div.p: Etienne Audureau is an Associate Professor in public health, physician, epidemiologist and biostatistician with an expertise in complex modelling of objective and self-rated health outcomes like health related quality of life (HRQoL) and implementation of e-health solutions for enhancing clinical research and management. As deputy director of CEpiA, he published 52 original articles in international peer reviewed journals, covering the multilevel analysis and modelling of the causal pathways in comorbidity occurrence and expression at the biological, individual and contextual levels. Of note for the STeM proposal, he is scientific responsible of the e-cohort web-based study Hémavie, which implements collection and follow-up of self-rated indicators through an internet platform in patients with myeloproliferative syndromes, has developed the web-based platform of the Mondor Research Clinical Unit (URC) to allow remote follow-up of clinical research studies, and is principal investigator of the multicentre DeQolAge cohort study aimed at assessing the individual and environmental determinants of HRQoL in older cancer patients and their main caregivers. His capabilities cover advanced statistical and machine learning techniques applied to high-dimensional data with an expertise in bioinformatics applied to epidemiology and software programming (4 software solutions for statistics and data visualization developed).

Florence Canouï-Poitrine is an Associate Professor in public health, physician, epidemiologist and methodologist. She is coordinator or scientific leader for 4 multicenter cohorts or trials in hospital-based or ambulatory geriatric setting. Of note for the STEM proposal, she had an expertise of tele-health solutions applied to geriatric populations, and have led or been actively involved 4 research projects (GERIATRIX, T4H, TELDERM, TSN), aiming to enhance health professional cooperation (at home, nursing homes and hospitals) for improved geriatric patient management and continuity of care Role in the project: Fraunhofer IIS will implement a wireless transmission prototype based on OpenAirInterface, which is an open source software stack for basestations (LTE: eNodeB; 5G: gNodeB) and Modems (UE) . This 5G implementation is used for the evaluation of latest 5G technology in the area of eHealth applications, in advance to commercially available 5G equipment. Within the eHealth^5G project, Fraunhofer IIS is planning to extend the OpenAir5G functionality within WP4 and to support field trials within WP5 for selected use cases as defined by all partners in WP2.

div.head: Experts involved:
div.p: Thomas Heyn received his degree in electrical engineering (Dipl.Ing.) from the Friedrich-Alexander-University in Erlangen in 1996.

He joined Fraunhofer Institute for Integrated Circuits in 1996 where he has been working in several national and international projects in the area of telecommunication and digital broadcasting systems for contracting authorities as well as industrial partners. He is head of the Connectivity Group within the Broadcast and Broadband Department, member of the networld2020 European Technology Platform and active in 3GPP. His current research interests include future mobile networks investigating 4G LTE-A technologies and beyond like eMBMS and its evolvments, the integration of satellite in 5G as well as the Ultra reliable low latency communication (URLLC) aspects of 4G and 5G for use cases like eHealth and industrial automation. He is attending the 3GPP RAN plenaries since September 2015 and partly RAN1 working group meetings. Role in the project: KPI will develop a mobile application for health status monitoring of patients having medical treatment at home (on example of diabetes patients). KPI will also contribute into development of privacy protection solutions.

div.head: Experts involved:
div.p: Prof. Sergiy Shukayev (male). Doctor of Technical Sciences, Chief of the International Projects Office of Igor Sikorsky Kyiv Polytechnic Institute, responsible for international cooperation. He is an author of three methodology books and more than 140 scientific publications. He is very experienced in management of international projects funded under UNESCO, STCU, TEMPUS, ERASMUS MUNDUS, FP7, Horizon 2020, Erasmus+ and other programs. He promotes participation of Igor Sikorsky Kyiv Polytechnic Institute and its subdivisions in the international programs.

Prof. Ivan Dychka (male). Doctor of Technical Sciences (Computer Engineering), NTUU "KPI" (2004). Professor (2007). He is a Head of the Computer Systems Software Department and a Dean of the Faculty of Applied Mathematics of the National Technical University of Ukraine "Igor Sikorsky Kyiv Polytechnic Institute". He is an author of more than 130 scientific articles.

Dr. Lesiya Liushenko (female). PhD of mathematical modelling (1995) from Kyiv Polytechnic Institute. She is a Senior Researcher at Computer Systems Software Department of the National Technical University of Ukraine "Igor Sikorsky Kyiv Polytechnic Institute". She is also an internationally Certified Projects Director IPMA Level А.

div.head: Mälardalen University (MDH)
div.p: Mälardalen University (MDH) is a young and modern university focusing on applied research and education in close cooperation with industry. Embedded Systems (ES) is the leading research environmentat the School of Innovation, Design and Engineering (IDT) at MDH, and holds the leading position in Sweden in real.time systems research The research at ES is organized in 6 mutually supportive and cooperating groups that focus on(i) Dependable Systems, (ii) Real-Time Systems, (iii) Robotics and Avionics, (iv) Sensor Systems And Health, (v) Software Engineering, (vi) Verification and Validation. . ES hosts several large strategic initiatives in close collaboration with Swedish industry, such as the Dependable Platforms for Autonomous Systems and Control, and Embedded Sensor Systems for Health research profiles. On the international level, ES as extensive cooperation worldwide (Software Engineering Institute/CMU, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Georgia Tech., University of York, Karlsruhe University, University of Cantabria, Seoul National University, RMIT University, University of L'Aquila, INRIA, Åalborg University, Vrije University-Amsterdam, etc.). Industrial partners include major companies, such as ABB, Ericsson, Volvo AB, Volvo Cars, Bombardier and Scania, as well as a number of SMEs. MDH is actively promoting exploitation of research by employing business developers and supporting incubators. Commercial products emerging from the MDH/ES research include a componentbased development environment (Arcticus Systems), a real-time database (Mimer), a realtime debugger (Zealcore), reverse engineering tools (Percepio), and the UPPAAL model checker for real-time systems (UPP4ALL -in cooperation with Uppsala University and Åalborg University).

Role in the project: Within Health^5G, MDH will lead tasks T2.2, T3.3, and T5.3, and will contribute with expertise and solutions on system architecture, design of IoT platforms, network management and re-configurability techniques, as well as techniques for the verification and validation of demonstrators.

He has been very active in introducing learning approaches for network management e.g., proactive mobility management, resource allocation, dynamic end-to-end configuration, etc. He has also been involved in design and development of large scale demonstrator including LTE, virtual EPC, integration of OpenStack with Opendaylight for SDNized WLAN, etc. User-centric network selection, resource allocation, and Quality of Experience (QoE) in future wirelesses networks and in distributed cloud computing systems are some of his other research interests. He was the recipient of several best paper awards and appreciation certificates. Manzoor is the author of several scientific publications including conference papers, journal articles, and book chapters.

Sebastian Peters is a Ph.D. student and researcher at the DAI-Labor, TU Berlin. He obtained his M. Sc. Degree from TU Berlin in 2010. During his master thesis, he was involved in the conceptual development and implementation of a novel user-centric decision maker for multiservice handover. Developed for the EU FP7 project Perimeter, this decision maker is able to exploit the distributed subjective Quality of Experience reports of many end users, and infer the congestion status of all the different administrative domains. His thesis also included a wide survey on the usage of ontology based semantics in network management practices of today and the future.

div.head: Gasera Oy
div.p: Company profile: Gasera, a hi-tech technology company from Finland that was established in 2004 with the mission of producing cutting edge measurement equipment for reliable analysis of gases, liquids, and solid materials. Company specialises in the development of portable, accurate, highly sensitive and selective measuring devices for extreme conditions. Our technology solutions are based on photoacoustic spectroscopy (PAS), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) principle and widely scanning mid-infrared lasers. Our technical know-how along with ownership of the intellectual property rights, guarantees that all our products meet the high demands of today's measuring equipment market. The main applications for our technology solutions are in protecting humans and the environment by measuring the toxic air pollutants of indoor and outdoor air. Other markets served include environmental research, medical, power utility, food safety, energy, industrial process control, and security. We currently employ 38 highly educated specialists from the areas of physics, chemistry, mechanics, electronics and business.

Role in the project: Gasera Oy will provide instrument development to provide 5G enabled equipment for hospital care case. Gasera will also provide cloud system development, which enables secure data collection and management with utilization of 5G communication. Gasera will contribute to development of future standards creation by providing feedback on 5G development to accommodate high data sensor volumes..

div.head: Experts involved:
div.p: Dr Ismo Kauppinen (male) Ismo received his MSc. and PhD. in physics from the University of Turku, Finland, in 1999 and 2002, respectively. He worked as a technical assistant, research assistant, assistant, and laboratory manager at the University of Turku during the years 1992-2001. He has worked as a managing director in a technology transfer company Noveltech Solutions Ltd from 2000 to 2004 and he is the founder of the company and a major shareholder. Currently he is a board member of Noveltech Solutions Ltd. He is also chairman of the board and a shareholder in a Finnish advertisement agency, Panic Marketing Ltd. Currently his position is CEO in Gasera Ltd, where he is also one of the founders. He has authored several peer-reviewed articles about audio signal processing and spectroscopy and he has several patents or patent applications Dr Tuomas Hieta (male) Tuomas received his D.Sc. (Tech) degree in the field of applied laser spectroscopy and electrical engineering at the Helsinki University of Technology (Finland) in 2011. He has worked as a researcher and a senior research scientist at MIKES Metrology and at VTT in the field of industrial and environmental laser sensing applications. During his period at MIKES and VTT his has coordinated a large FP7 project (MetAMC) focusing on sub-ppb generation and measurement of reactive airborne contaminants. In addition, he has co-founded a high-tech startup Optoseven Oy. Significant part of his work has included direct collaboration with industry and R&D organizations, which has led to a broad network of contacts in both of the aforementioned fields

div.head: VESTEL Electronics
div.p: Company profile: The VESTEL groups of companies (VESTEL) engage in research and product development, manufacturing, sales and marketing in the consumer electronics, white goods and digital product segments with an expertise in embedded systems design, implementation, testing, integration and manufacturing on consumer electronics, information communication technologies, and digital broadcast receiving technologies, electronic media and networking.

VESTEL Electronics is the the largest consumer electronics ODM/OEM Company in Europe. The company employs approximately 6000 people and its total revenue is €2.67 billion. VESTEL develops its R&D activities are carried out with approx. 500 experts in national and international research and development centers. VESTEL Electronics consist of 2 R&D Headquarters, Digital R&D, ITU Techno Park (Vestek in Istanbul), ODTU Techno Park and Cabot UK in its structure.

The primary focus of R&D activities is related to platform digitalization, high-definition, mobility and connectivity. VESTEL includes a variety of products to its customers including but not limited to LCD, PVR, IPTV, Patient IPTV, Billboard IPTV Hotel TV, DVD Players/Recorders, PVR box, DVB-T , Digital Signage and Set-top-boxes (DVB-T/C/S, DVB-T PVR STB, IP STB, HDD DVD Recorder, Wireless products), home network systems, notebook PCs and household appliances.

And also VESTEL has acquired Birim Information Technologies Trade Company in the beginning of 2006 to provide hardware, software and infrastructure solutions in Health sector as well as integrated health information management systems for hospitals and clinics. In addition, Birim employs more than 4500 member of staffs with 350 management employees in regional ten headquarters in Turkey. The Company has taken place fifth in 50 best software companies and 76th in informatics companies in Turkey. Birim Service Fields; Health Care Informatics Applications, Hospital Information Management Systems, Primary Health Care Center Information Systems, Family Physician IS, County Health IS, and National Health IS. Our New Technologies are Patient TV, Mobile Applications, and Voice Recognition Systems, PACS (Picture Archiving and Communication Systems), Telemedicine Systems). Related with, VESTEL took place as a partner of a group which was gave project offer to first call of 'Intelligent Object Network for Home Care for Ageing People' in concept of FP7 ICT 2007-1.
Role in the project: Vestel is an industrial partner of the Health 5G project. Vestel's expertise in consumer electronics devices and multimedia technologies will be utilized in the project.
